_prev_prog_3.Description: Process Safety Management (PSM) program is in effect in this facility. Through the use of scheduling and tracking the various preventative maintenance procedures, inspections with corrective follow-up, oil analysis, vibration analysis and UT testing, the ammonia system is monitored and repaired. The Boiler / Compressor Operators (BCO) are trained and complete the RETA refrigeration course. The BCO's are involved in writing and editing of the SOP's. They participate in PSM meetings, which are held at least quarterly. They are aware of the results of audits and inquiries.The program is reviewed and revised as necessary.

3.0     EXECUTIVE SUMMARY (2745.3)



3.1    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



    OLAM uses anhydrous ammonia for freezing vegetable products. Ammonia is the only hazardous chemical used at this facility that is subject to the CalARP program or the Federal RMP requirements.



    This facility recognizes the hazards associated with the use of highly hazardous chemicals.  As a reflection of our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State and local laws and regulations, we submit this plan to address the hazards inherent with the use of ammonia.  Our program addresses safety precautions regarding the handling and operation of this covered system as well as proper training for those who operate and maintain the system. The company training policy requires that all employees will be properly trained for a job position before assignment to that job. Operators are required to participate in Refrigerating Engineers and Technicians Association (RETA) training and become certified as a condition of employment.



    Our accidental release prevention program is clearly defined by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program for this facility. This prevention program follows industry-recommended standards for preventing unnecessary human exposures and reducing the threat to the health of our employees as well as to members of the community and the surrounding area. Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle these chemicals, the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility and its processes, and the training that we provide our personnel. This Plan is being updated in 2012, due to a  CHANGE in OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS as required by law. Any future changes to the system necessitating update will be addressed at that time.



    Our Emergency Action Plan (EAP) details the response this facility will take as a result of an uncontrolled release of ammonia. The Plan includes procedures for notification of the local emergency responder

s. This EAP also includes specific protocol for responding to an ammonia release and assigns an Emergency Coordinator to implement the response. This Plan is current and updated as required by law and conforms to the requirements for an Emergency Action Plan as per 29 CFR A?A? 1910.38(a).



    This facility has also coordinated with the local emergency responders and will maintain close contact to ensure that the responders are familiar with the system and with the general safety and accidental release program at our plant.



    It is the policy of this facility to devote the time, energy and capital toward maintaining prevention and response programs appropriate to the inherent dangers with the use of hazardous chemicals.     



3.2    THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The Stationary Source:



    The OLAM facility is located in the agriculturally productive Central Valley in Modesto, California. The plant is situated at about 90 feet above sea level at the southern border of the city limits of Modesto along Whitmore Avenue. The historically agricultural land south of Whitmore Avenue has been developed for residential use in the City of Ceres, California. The Union Pacific Railroad tracks separate the facility on the west from light agricultural businesses and a commercial strip mall. The Post Foods facility borders the northern property line and shares the same gated entrance on Whitmore Avenue. Approximately 40 acres of agricultural land lie to the east, which is subsequently bordered by Morgan Road on the eastern border. There is a commercial development consisting of a convenience / gasoline store and small food service stores.



    The OLAM facility, operated since 1958, processes vegetables into a variety of bulk dehydrated and / or frozen products. The facility operates three shifts throughout the year with some variance depending on crop variability.  Raw vegetables are trucked to the site and unloaded prior to the washing in the wet processin

g building. Once the vegetables have been washed, they are processed, dehydrated and / or frozen and packaged. The frozen vegetables may be re-blended for specific customers, and this involves refrigeration capability.



    Plant Security is provided by a guard located at the main gate entrance to the facility. The security guard provides emergency response support under the direction of the Emergency Coordinator. The entire plant is enclosed by a chain-link fence, except at the main gate, where trucks and personnel enter and exit as directed by the security guard. Electronic identification pass cards are required for vehicle entrance through the main gate to enter the plant area. Fingerprint recognition is used within the plant as a clock-in device.The Ammonia Room entrance is protected by a key code locking device. Process and office buildings are fire-sprinklered and connected to a centralized automated alarm system. The alarm has Voice Evacuation capability and can offer instructions pertinent to an event.

Regulated Substance Handled:



    The OLAM facility uses anhydrous ammonia (NH3) as a heat transfer fluid in the plant refrigeration system. The system is a hybrid one stage / two stage mechanical refrigeration system that utilizes a re-circulated liquid evaporator feed for product freezing. The closed loop system uses both liquid pumped overfeed and flooded systems. The system operates and is attended 24 hours day each day of the year by a qualified system operator.



    The current capacity of the system is 658 TR, operating at a low-stage saturated suction temperature of - 40A?A? F (8.8 psig). High stage saturated suction temperature is + 25A?A? F (38.9 psig) with a saturated discharge temperature of + 115 A?A?F (250 psig).

      

The Primary System Components include:

o    Five (5) High Stage Compressors (HSC 1-5)

o    One (1) Single Stage Swing Compressor (SWC-1)

o    Three (3) Low Stage Screw Compressors (LSC 1-3)

o    Three (3) Evaporative Condensers (EC 1-3)

o    T

wo (2) High Stage Pressure Receivers (HPR 1-2)

o    One (1) Intercooler (IC 1)

o    Nine (9) Oil Separators (OS-XXX-Y)

o    Two (2) Suction Accumulators (SA-1-2)

o    Two (2) Precooler Surge Drums (SD-1-2)

o    Two (2) Liquid Recirculator Packages (LRP 1-2)

o    Two (2) Freezer Belt Coils (FF-1-2)

o    Five (5) Ammonia Pumps (AP-1-4, 7)

o    One (1) Liquid Transfer Unit (LTU-1)

o    Six (6) Air Cooling Evaporators (EV 1-5, MAU-1)



The Compressors, the Intercooler and the High Pressure Receivers and Liquid Recirculator Package 2 are located in the Engine Room. The Condensers, Suction Accumulators and the Liquid Transfer Unit are located on the Engine Room Roof. Other equipment is located in and above the Production Areas for CM-1 and CM-2.



Additional System Components include:



    Two (2) Oil Pots (OP-1-2) One at each Liquid Recirculator Package (LRP 1-2),    used for draining oil from system.    

One (1) Auto-Purger    One (1) Ammonia Diffusion Tank



      Safety Systems include:    



Pressure Relief Valves and Pressure Relief Piping to     Ammonia Diffusion Tank

    Liquid Level Float Switches

    Ventilation System for continuous and emergency ventilation of the Engine Room

    Ammonia detection and Alarm System for response to elevated levels of ammonia vapor in the Engine Room and Production Freezer area.

    Emergency Refrigeration Control Switch for emergency shutdown of the system.     Fire Sprinkler system

    Fire Extinguishers

    Emergency Showers and Eyewash Stations

    Ammonia Diffusion Tank designed to contain the ammonia released by the Pressure Relief Valves

    Escape Hoods and other approved Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) for Boiler-Compressor Operators (BCO) use in an emergency

    Alarm System contains Voice Evacuation System for communication of instructions during incident, and differential signals for a      fire or a chemical incident. The operation and maintenance staff consists of one (1) trained and certified Boiler-Compressor Operator (BCO) per shift at a minimum.

 

E

QUIPMENT DESCRIPTION:



    Compressors: create suction to pull low pressure vapor from the source and pressurize the vapor to a high-side discharge of a superheated gas / liquid / vapor mix.



    Evaporative Condensers: receive high pressure vapor from the main discharge header common to the high side discharge of compressors (except for low-stage compressors). The evaporative condenser rejects all the heat of the system to the atmosphere or evaporating water. The pumped liquid from the re-circulator packages enters the evaporators and part (up to 25%) of the liquid flashes to vapor. The resulting mixture of liquid / vapor will gravity flow back to the re-circulator package. 



    Suction Accumulators: designed to reduce liquid carryover back to the compressors which can be damaging to the compressors. The vapor from the Liquid Recirculating Package enters its dedicated suction accumulator. The sizing allows for the separation of liquid and vapor. The vapor is sent to the booster (low-side) compressors which pressurize it and begin the cycle again. The gas / liquid / vapor mix flows into the high side compressors for increased pressurization and then on to the evaporators for the flash to vapor.



    Evaporators: remove heat from water or air. The heat in the water or air transfers to the liquid ammonia and causes the liquid to flash and become a low-pressure vapor.  



    Intercooler: receives intermediate pressure vapor from the discharge header of the compressors. As the vapor bubbles through 10 A?A? F liquid in the Intercooler it is cooled and desuperheated. The second function of the Intercooler is to sub-cool high pressure liquid from the high pressure receivers before the liquid goes to the Liquid Recirculator Packages.



    High Pressure Receivers: Receive the High Pressure Liquid from the evaporative condensers by gravity flow and store the liquid until it is needed by the Liquid Recirculator Package (via the Intercooler).    Liquid Recirculator Packages: Utilize th

e ammonia pumps to pump low pressure liquid to the freezer coils.



    Auto-Purger: removes the non-condensable substances from the system. The non-condensable gases are also known as foul gases. Air and water can enter the system through leaks on the low side of the system because it is under vacuum. Ammonia which is likely to be contaminated by the non-condensable gases is introduced to the Auto-Purger. The Auto-Purger refrigerates this vapor and condenses the ammonia. The remaining vapor is bubbled through water and released to the atmosphere.



    Ammonia Diffusion Tank: The system is designed to contain the ammonia in the event of a massive release such as would be caused by a fire. The tank contains one (1) gallon of water for every pound of ammonia in the system. The tank also has sufficient head space for the ammonia to mix with the water and form a solution of ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH). The solution can be safely disposed of, pending instructions from appropriate Authority Having Jurisdiction. Pre-treatment to neutralize the solution may be required before discharge to the sewer system of the City of Modesto.



    Emergency Control Panel: the Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) is pre-programmed to respond to signals from the Ammonia Detection System and is capable of shutting down the system by cutting off power to the compressors, closing the King Valves (to restrict the flow of ammonia)  and operating the ventilation fans. 



    Alarm and Detection System: In the event of a fire or an ammonia leak above the set levels, the Alarm System will notify the employees with an alarm and a voice evacuation message. The Alarm System components are on an electrically supervised circuit to maintain electrical integrity of the system.



A. Infrared Ammonia Detector: Air is sampled through a chamber and the infrared light is at the correct wavelength (bandwidth) to absorb ammonia and a correlation can be made to the concentration. It triggers an alarm to alert there is

ammonia in the air.



B. Electrochemical Ammonia Detector: Liquid electrolyte is enclosed in a housing with a permeable membrane that allows ammonia vapor to come in contact with the solution. The electrode measures change in potential.



3.3     THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



        This facility complies with the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP) and OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM). Key prevention steps taken by this facility to maintain safety are outlined in the PSM Program. These include the description of all system and equipment information, Process Hazard Analysis, operator training, contractor qualification, Standard Operating Procedures, Pre-Startup Safety Review, hot work permitting, and formalized Management of Change, Mechanical Integrity, Incident Investigation, compliance audits and emergency response.



        Those who operate, maintain, or supervise the system will be trained to understand the principles of ammonia refrigeration and ammonia properties, an understanding of the process equipment and proper operating and maintenance procedures, recognition of abnormal conditions and the steps to correct deviations. The steps to execute an emergency shutdown procedure as appropriate to the level of involvement each employee will have with the process. Contractors that perform the maintenance or that design changes to the system will be qualified by the facility based upon their experience and safety record before being selected to provide such services.



    The general safety program includes hazardous communication, forklift operations, first aid, emergency response, Confined space entry restrictions, line break permits, and additional programs as necessary to maintain a safe operation, particularly in elevated areas.



3.4    THE FIVE (5) YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



    On March 18-20, 2011 approximately 6,000 pounds of ammonia was released due to a coil being punct

ured by a welder working in the vicinity.



3.5    THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



    Employees are trained to understand the requirements of the Emergency Action Plan. The Emergency Action Plan includes release notification for emergency responders and the procedures for evacuation. The Emergency Coordinator implements the response in coordination with the local emergency responders (i.e. the fire department). It is the policy and practice to conduct evacuation drills at least twice per year.



3.6    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



    A revalidation Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed as required every five (5) years at a minimum. The PHA team developed a list of recommendations to improve safety by reducing potential hazards of the process. All recommendations were implemented, deemed unnecessary since no improvements to safety would result, or planned for implementation at a later date. The next scheduled PHA is to be completed early Spring 2013.



Upcoming events include:



    Improved Standard Operating Procedures

    Additional Training for Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)

    PLC for the Refrigeration System has had several programming upgrades to improve the overall performance. That will be ongoing.
